“Illuminati" was a secret society that operated for about a decade, between 1776 and 1785, in Bavaria. It was originally known as “The Order of the Illuminati” and was founded by Adam Weishaupt (1748-1830), a German law professor who educated young members about reasoning and rational thought, philanthropy, social justice and quality of life, so that if and when the members came to power in future, they could influence political decisions. This was mainly working against monarchy that was prevalent at the time. To start with, the group was very small; just a handful of people, eventually growing to about 2,000 strong and continued to recruit members who thought the same way about monarchy and imperialism. The original Order of the Illuminati were not very successful. In 1785, the then Duke of Bavaria, Karl Theodor (1742-1777) banned all secret societies, including the Illuminati, and anyone who continued to support the Illuminati were severely punished. The Illuminati literally disappeared. However, some historians think that the Illuminati just disappeared from public view, but it continued growing steadily in an arcane manner, and virtually took over the world. It is thought they still control the world today. It may be true, because, if a group of powerful and influential people really ‘dominate’ the world today, we probably wouldn't know about it. Once the Order of the Illuminati was disbanded, conspiracy theories about the group sprang up. A conspiracy theory is an attempt to explain harmful or tragic events as the result of the actions of a small but powerful group of people. The theory usually rejects the media-published explanation of the events. In fact, the official explanation may be seen as covering up some deeper significance, a conspiracy. The Illuminati was accused of infiltrating the Freemasons, another secret organization that began in early 18th century that focussed on morality, charity, and obedience to the law of the land. Illuminati, was even blamed for causing the French Revolution. Similarly, there is a long line of conspiracy theories, proving the group’s power and influence throughout history. Several Presidents of the United States such as George Washington and Thomas Jefferson were believed to be members of the Order of the Illuminati. Dan Brown's popular novel Angels and Demons depicts the Illuminati as observing strange rituals, Satanism, alien myths, and other ideas. At the end of the day, we may say that the Illuminati doesn’t exist anymore. Or maybe not. For more information: Illuminati - Wikipedia

Describing the historical Illuminati as just "a group of free thinkers" is a bit misleading. The order was essentially geared towards a strict regime of moral education, which involved writing monthly confessionals (the "quibus licet" reports) and spying on other members, as well as using the order's influences to get the supposedly morally superior initiates influential positions in order to slowly reform society to a utopian state where everyone would be so rational that any form of government would no longer be necessary. Adam Weishaupt, the founder, was heavily influenced by the writings of Antoine Court de Gébelin and Jean-Jacques Rousseau, who were both really big on ideas like primitivism and the noble savage. At the same time, the order was also extremely deceptive, using a variety of myths (such as claiming to be descendants of the Knights Templar) to attract members and it also had a very radical required reading list. As members advanced in the order, they were expected to read scandalous literature like d'Holbach's Christianity Unveiled. Until the Bavarian government published Einige Originalschriften des Illuminatenordens and Nachtrag von Weitern Originalschriften in 1787, two large collections of confiscated order documents and really the main source of what we know about the order, the only real information on the Illuminati came from disgruntled defectors, especially the juridical deposits of Joseph Utzschneider and two of his colleagues, Cosandey and Grünberg. Joseph II had tried to take advantage of a succession dispute in 1777, when Karl Theodor had become the heir of Bavaria despite not really wanting it (he was already the Elector of the Palatinate), to achieve his goals but ended up losing a war against Frederick the Great instead. However, Joseph II had a new plan in 1783, which a majority within the Munich branch of the Illuminati supported, and Marie Anne had written to Frederick the Great to help put a stop to it. The Illuminati (plural of Latin illuminatus, "enlightened") is a name given to several groups, both real and fictitious. Historically, the name usually refers to the Bavarian Illuminati, an Enlightenment-era secret society founded on 1 May 1776. The society's goals were to oppose superstition, obscurantism, religious influence over public life, and abuses of state power. "The order of the day," they wrote in their general statutes, "is to put an end to the machinations of the purveyors of injustice, to control them without dominating them." The Illuminati—along with Freemasonry and other secret societies—were outlawed through edict by the Bavarian ruler Charles Theodore with the encouragement of the Catholic Church, in 1784, 1785, 1787, and 1790. In the following several years, the group was vilified by conservative and religious critics who claimed that they continued underground and were responsible for the French Revolution. Many influential intellectuals and progressive politicians counted themselves as members, including Ferdinand of Brunswick and the diplomat Xavier von Zwack, who was the Order's second-in-command. It attracted literary men such as Johann Wolfgang von Goethe and Johann Gottfried Herder and the reigning dukes of Gotha and Weimar. In subsequent use, "Illuminati" has referred to various organisations which have claimed or have been claimed to be connected to the original Bavarian Illuminati or similar secret societies, though these links have been unsubstantiated. These organisations have often been alleged to conspire to control world affairs, by masterminding events and planting agents in government and corporations, in order to gain political power and influence and to establish a New World Order. Central to some of the more widely known and elaborate conspiracy theories, the Illuminati have been depicted as lurking in the shadows and pulling the strings and levers of power in dozens of novels, films, television shows, comics, video games, and music videos.

People often feel some level of paranoia. We often feel as if there are big things happening that we are unaware of. And often this is true, to some extent. City planners here in town are probably discussing changing some roads or other things that will influence a small part of my life in the future (making me take a detour, for example). It is easy to think that there must be a big conspiracy going on, of powerful people, trying to hide what is really going on. Believing that such a thing exists allows you to abdicate responsibility (since you are just one person and cannot possibly do anything if there is such a big and powerful group) and it gives you someone to blame for things that go wrong. How things actually happen is much less exciting. I’d recommend you watch “Yes, Minister” and “Parks and Recreation” to get a feeling of what politics is really like, and to see how powerful and rich people try to and are sometimes able to influence politics. A lot of it is not hidden, if you know where to look.
